transcript.content: Hives there on XFM 104.9, I'm Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant...
..is with you.
Oh yeah, sentences and all that.
Just using the traditional English language.
Well you pointed at me, you put me off, you pointed to yourself and I just said Steve Merchant.
Well, you know, we do that every week you introduce me, you say 'with me' and I say Steve Merchant.
No! Yeah.
So that's a catchphrase that everyone's waiting to hear Rick.

Yeah, but usually I go 'Ricky Gervais' and that and you go 'with Steve Merchant', but this time you pointed to you so I said it, but I didn't say it, it, err, uh, caught me off guard, so I didn't use the sentence.

Oh, I don't like the way you sit, right, I've read medically that if you sit slouching like that, can you try and describe how you're sat, you've got the kind of m... have you ever seen that picture when John Lennon was off his head on smack recording Let It Be, and he was lying on the floor at Abbey Road, that's basically what Ricky looks like now.
I keep getting chest pains, I'm scared.
It's not good for you that, look at the, your not, you can't breathe properly in the diaphragm so you're gonna get speak badly...
Ricky cackles at Steve's linguistic befuddlement.
Eh, listen, I was trying to speak medical stuff there, it was bound to end in trouble. Anyway Rick, what are the words to Wham Rap? No, what are the words to Wh... I don't remember Wham Rap.
(rapping) “Hey sucker, what the hell's go into you, de, de, de, de, de, de, de, de, de la de, de, hey suckerrrrr, now there's nothing you can do.”

Brilliant, I look forward to a forthcoming revival of your music career. Rick I had some devastating news last night, you know after I left you I was off to buy a PlayStation 2, I was totally in the mood for it...
Or a 'PS2' as he said.
Yeah, yeah, which confused him, granddad.
Ricky cackles at this generational contumeliousness.
So I think I went in some electrical stop on Oxford Street and...
Can I just say, the thing about Steve is, I wouldn't say he's mean, cos he hates that, erm, he's careful right, he will, he will spend days to get a pound off.

Rick, two and a half hours I walked round last night, I swear to god, I was walking round to different shops , I went from Oxford Street to Piccadilly Circus and back again, along the length of Oxford Street, back again, all over the place, right, basically couldn't get a better deal than about 240 quid, for a console and a game so I ended up in Virgin Megastore, I bought a... I bought Auto Grand Theft 3 or whatever, and a PlayStation and a memory card, whatever, so I'm shooting off, I'm walking off, I'm going to the tube and I walk all the way to HMV, on err, opposite Bond Street, i just popped in there cos I'd forgotten to get something and I went downstairs and I was walking past the PlayStations and it went 'if you buy a PlayStation 2 you can get Grand Theft Auto 3 with twenty pounds off'.
Oh...
I was absolutely devastated.
What did you so?

I just, I, I, I, I crumbled, I didn't know what to do, I was thinking of taking it back to Virgin Megastore going 'it's faulty', “well how can it be faulty, you haven't got it home yet?” 'Oh I can tell...'
'No, I didn't mean to buy this though', “what did you mean to buy?”...'keyboard'... I meant to...

Exactly, and I get it back and I wire it up and that and all I can see as the cars are racing around the track, all I can see is, it's like one of those cartoons when a really hungry bloke can just see one of his mates as a big chicken, all I could see on the screen was a twenty pound note floating, it was an absolute nightmare, I'm just  devastated by it. Twenty quid! I could have bought like another cheap game for that.
We went to the, did I tell you this, we went to...
Rick, would you give me twenty pounds, then I'll shut up about it.

Yeah, yeah, we went to the casino once, a group of us and I lost about £100, and it was, it was great, it was someone's birthday, I think it was Jane's birthday, and Steve after three hours of gambling, had lost the twenty pounds he got out to play with, right, I was going 'you're really gutted aren't you?', he went “do you know, have you any idea how much cheese I could get for twenty pounds?”

Yeah. Cold meats. For twenty pounds, and now there it is again last night, twenty pounds. I'm robbed of twenty pounds. Literally they've taken it from my hand, the HMV people, they've taken that and they've pissed it away.
I can't believe it, I'm gonna think of some things to cheer you up, shall we play some songs?
Frontier Psychiatrist – The Avalanches.
Avalanches there, Frontier Psychiatrist.
I never enjoy any record, where I think I, or a four year old could have made it, do you know what I mean, it's just like it's cheating, it's musical cheating.
Yeah, I'm not a big fan of that one, we won't play that again then, alright, that's done, alright?
Shake on it.
Ricky and Steve shake hands.
Yeah, XFM 104.9...
Kiss on it...
Kiss on it, touch on it. Karl...

Karl, Karl came in this morning and said he was soaking wet, cos obviously it's miserable out, and actually if you're thinking of leaving the house today and thus missing the show, do not leave cos it's miserable out.
It's like a weather report as well, we play music, we've got chat, we have little jokes don't we? And it's raining.
Karl came in said he was soaking wet, I said to him, I said 'Rick would want you to do it', I want you to do it just, take your clothes off and pop 'em over there...
You know what...
And he wouldn't do it, and he said he was 'gonna do it, but I knew you'd say that.'
But when you left us in the kitchen, when he was making coffee, he went, 'Yeah', Steve said 'if you're wet, take your trousers off and I thought, oh hold on Ricky's not here, what's he up to?'
Ricky and Steve laugh.
No, I was talking on behalf of Rick, I phoned him up and said 'he's wet, what should I suggest?'
Well I said... I was in his ear, he had earpiece in, and I was going 'tell him it's bad for him' and I could hear him go 'it's bad for you'.., and I go 'tell him it...'
Rheumatism...
Yeah.
It could lead to rheumatism, drop 'em, take 'em off.
Ricky laughs at this suggestive suggestion.
Karl, Karl, speak, no-one's heard your voice today, come on Karl...
He doesn't want to.
Come on K-man, I know he doesn't, but we won't talk to you much.
Alright.
Go on.
It's just nice to say hello to you.
Alright.
I think people quite like to know you're here.
They tune in, they love to hear you. We've had some fan mail for you.
I like his little face, he's a little Moby, I drew a picture of him in the week, just doodling, and he got really insulted.
Did he?
Why did you get insulted?
It wasn't very good, I looked like Ian Camfield.
Ricky and Steve howl with laughter.
That's an insult, the ladies love Camfield. I mean they're weird kind of heavy metal ladies, but...

Yeah, the ones that drink blood. Yeah they love Camfield. I thought of who you looked like today, but I think you might find it insulting as well, but it's meant to be affectionate. You look like, for people who don't know what you look like, you look like Beaker out of the muppets.
(laughing) I can't see how that would be an insult.
Ricky howls at this riposte.
Oh god, it is when you put it like that, but it's sort of like, I like Beaker.
Yeah, but you like him cos he's a fool.
Ricky howls again.
He just goes, what does he do?
Ricky and Steve do Beaker impressions.
You look a bit like that doctor that used to accompany him everywhere, that professor.
Oh yeah, the little fat bloke.

The little fat one. Karl, what was it that you told me when you came in? Just Karl's thought of the day, Karl what did you tell me when you came in? Cos it was miserable out and you made a suggestion.
It is a grim day in London.
Ricky giggles.
I like it already.
Brilliant.
I was thinking, could you imagine dying today?
Ricky laughs.
Go on. Explain more though.
Just because when you're dying, you're always like in your bedroom, in your bed...
Always.
And your family's next door.
Always.

And I just thought, could you imagine lying there and looking out your window, cos they do that as well, they sort of have the curtains open to get a bit of light on your face. And I just thought what a day, if this was your last day could you imagine?
But go on then, you...
No, he made another, he made another more, even, even more profound point, you said, 'instead of dying on a rainy day you'd prefer to...'
No, if you died on a, a bit of a nicer, sunny day, then it's not so bad. No, it's your last day looking out on the world and look at it. Don't you agree?
I thought that was a beautiful point, it was poetic almost.
It was, wasn't it.

Cos, no, the point was, what upset me was you said that you'd been thinking about that today on the way in and it upset you, my point was if you think about the people that are dying any day, it'll upset you.
Yeah...
But do you see?
Yeah, but you don't think about it when it's sunny, cos you think they'll be alright today, they won't be that annoyed.
You're absolutely right Karl.
Annoyed! Annoyed! Think of that. “Oh I'm... ugh... I'm dying today...
“I'm dying.”
It was just, it was just when I got up and opened the curtains and though 'look at it'.
'I'm glad I'm not dying today.' Karl play a song.
You're interesting.
Mull Historical Society, Watching Xanadu, on XFM 104.9, I'm Ricky Gervais...
...with me Steve Merchant.
See it doesn't work if you say 'with me, Steve Merchant.
No, it doesn't work.
I've gotta say either, I've either gotta say 'with me, Steve Merchant' or you just go 'with Steve Merchant.'
Sure, sure, sure...
See what I mean, it's not as easy is it?
No, it's not, it's not as easy as it seems.
You know this, right... I mean...
What?
This radio show we do.
Oh right.
Well we come in and we don't plan anything, we just sort of like chat, and they still pay us, shall we just do this all day?
What all day on XFM or...?
Or just like, get a license, where it is just, it's Ricky and Steve FM and we just chat and we go 'what you doing there Steve?' Just having my breakfast.” just go 'oh right, yeah.'
Yeah, yeah.
“Oh, what you doing there Steve?”, 'Oh just cleaning the windows and that.' And we have a little chat and go 'oh just reading the paper' and we just talk and we play records.
For 24 hours a day?
Yeah.
I mean, have you spotted any flaws in that plan?
It would be boring after about an hour and a half.
Yeah.
Is that it?
Yeah.
Okay.
I mean, this is boring now and we've only done twenty minutes.
No, it's just that we were talking about Karl having a thought remember?
Yes, yes.
And then I had that thought, when I went out to get some orange juice, and I had that thought, so maybe this show could be about, let's have thoughts.
Okay.
Shall we have thoughts?
Yeah...
Okay then, and if we haven't got any they could phone in with some.
Or email a thought maybe if you've got a thought, you can email that in.
Yeah, we could just talk about it.
[email protected], could be a thought about anything.
It could be, go on...
Could not make those thoughts racist or homophobic though please?
Yeah, or, erm, not downers.
Yeah, nothing that's gonna bring us down. Upbeat stuff.
Yeah, go on Karl, you were gonna...
You know when you said '24 hours' then, you know how much it takes to run one of the escalators on the underground for twenty hours a day, how much it costs a year to do that?
How long, twenty hours a day?
That's what it runs...
Is this another one of your facts?
Hmm-hmm.
These are always, these are always substantiated by an independent source aren't they? They're not just something you overheard on a bus, just to check. This if fact.
I read it, I read it...
Where did you...?
Did you read it on a wall in like a sandwich shop?

Sometimes I wish this was on telly, because when Steve said 'these have been substantiated by an independent arbitrator...' or something, Karl just looked at him, like he'd just spoken French. He just looked like that...
Okay, so anyway this is information you got from a reliable source, you read it on the back of fag packet or something...
No, I think it was in The Metro magazine in the week.
Lovely.
Okay.
And what's the... let's just hear it again, how much does it cost...?
Yeah... there's loads of escalators in't there, on the underground and the run for twenty hours a day...
Don't tell us how, I tell you what Karl, that's such a fascinating fact, don't tell us, let's play a record Rick and then people can stay tuned if they wanna...

This is like, this is like some sort of mental home radio, isn't it, I mean we are, we are, we're not mentally ill, we haven't had any head trauma, erm, we're educated people, but we come out with just rubbish.
Gobbledygook.
Just nonsense, just like, I can't grasp, I don't know why he started saying that, I have no idea what that thought was...
You just said, you just said... 24 hours, about doing radio for 24 hours, so I remembered, I thought oh 20... 20 hours...
Ricky howls with laughter.
So, we're now examining the thought processes that we all have before we get to something, let's just hear a song...
Okay, it's half past one, and That Film Sounds Good.
Steve does sounds effect noises.
“That Film Sounds Good...”
“Feature, feature, feature...”

This is where I choose a song from a film... oh that films sounds good... see, this is a film me and Steve both love, and he actually saw it first and got me onto it and said I'd love it and I did, it was Rushmore, it's a great film and from it features one of my favourite artists of all time, The Wind by Cat Stevens and this is off the first album I ever bought, Teaser and The Firecat, this is The Wind from Rushmore... That Film Sounds Good...
Steve does more sound effects.
The Wind - Cat Stevens.
Cat Stevens, The Wind.
Elegant.
That's a beautiful song, the album is a superb album, it's seminal, there's some great songs on there, I feel like playing another one, maybe Song For The Lovers.
Maybe do it later.
Maybe we could do that. It's beautiful.

I have to say, I've seen the follow-up to Rushmore, if you enjoyed Rushmore, it's this new film The Royal Tenenbaums, with an amazing cast, Ben Stiller's in it, Gwyneth Paltrow and Gene Hackman in his Golden Globe winning performance. Same sort of things as Rushmore, same kind of style, but, lovely sort of kind of family comedy, absolute dynamite and again a brilliant soundtrack, Nico is on there, Nick Drake, all kinds of treats, forthcoming in the cinemas Rick.
You say the follow-up, is it the same director?
It's not a sequel, it's the same director, same writer, some of the same cast, Bill Murray makes another appearance, same style...
Haven't the Swingers lot done another one?
They have, their new films Made, Jon Favreau and Vince Vaughn, again dynamite, really good fun, not as kind of perceptive as Swingers, but certainly as much fun.
Have you seen Swingers Karl?
I think so, is it the one where, they've got a line in it, they've got a catchphrase in it, haven't they?
You're the money.
Money.
No.
You're so money.
That's it. Yeah I have seen it.
I love the fact that I said 'you're the money', he went no, you went “you're so money”' he went yeah.
Ricky laughs uproariously.
Well, yeah, yours is from whathisname...
Yeah, Jerry Maguire...
No, that's 'show me the money'.
Yeah... yeah...
I've seen it.
Anyway...
See, see that was really articulate, we did a feature it linked into films, Steve loves films, he did a little off-the-cuff review, then it went into gobblygook again... I can't even say it.
Yeah... you couldn't even say the word gobbledygook. Anyway you had an interesting fact you were gonna give us Karl, I don't think we can leave people waiting for this any longer.
Right.
Ricky and Steve giggle.

How much does it cost to run one escalator, that's just one, on a London Underground, it's running 20 hours a day cos it shuts for four hours in the night, when they're cleaning it and that, how much does it cost to run it for a year?
Twelve pounds.
Sixty thousand pounds.
The trouble with these facts is, I've got nothing to compare it against.
Well, think about like, your yearly electric bill... at home.
Well, when you put it like that, when you...
It's a lot innit, when you think they could just use stairs.
Karl, play a song... politics on XFM 104.9, please people just use the stairs.
Chemical Brothers, Star Guitar, I'm gonna be honest Steve, I like the video more than the song.
Agreed.

Good, I just wish, we could maybe tape the bits we're not on air, for people, that's when Karl comes into his own, he just said to me, I was, I don't know what I was doing, I was sort of like pottering around, dancing around, doing something annoying probably, and he just looked around at me, I turned around, he was looking at me and I looked back and he, and he went “have you ever used a Y-front properly?”
Genius.
It's a great question, cos the answer's definitely 'no'.
Definitely no.

Has anyone, does anyone use their Y-front properly and by that I mean get your winky out the little, sort of – slot provided; as opposed to put it to one side or pull 'em down or whatever. Has anyone used a Y-front properly?
I don't think I've ever done it.
I don't think I've ever done it.
I've never seen anyone in a toilet doing it Rick.
You shouldn't be looking.
(Laughing) I wish I hadn't said that.
(Cackling) I caught ya! Really?
Yeah. That's actually how you prove people are gay.
Yeah.
You get 'em into this conversation.
Yeah, yeah and it's a trap.
Yeah and it's a trap.
It was a, it was, it was, it was, it was a trap.
I'm not gay by the way.
I always thought it was the...
You didn't think I was gay, I double bluffed ya...
Ricky cackles.
Cos I knew the old gay trick.
I always thought it was the “old gaylords say 'no' thing.”
That is another method, there's innumerable methods of doing it.
That's how Oscar Wilde was caught.
Yeah.
Yeah.
What happened there?
Well the judge went to him- “Did you see that film last night Gaylords Say No?” and he went 'no' and they went “take him away”.
Yeah, take him down to the cells.
Yeah, take him to Reading.
It is true.
Um...well.
That is true, it originated in America.
Yeah.
So many of these things do. It's a brilliant point Karl, I'd like to hear from anyone, anyone listening who's, and I mean, uh, well, they'll just lie won't they, that's what they'll do.
I don't even sort of use flies.
No?
Usually, I sort of just, sort of, pull my Y-front, uh, my sort-of tracksuit down, that's why I sort of wear elasticated waistband all the time.
Exactly, speed!
Ricky cackles.
Yeah!
You've gotta get in there with the minimum of effort.
Yeah, wee and out...
Sure, sure.
Often I won't shake...
No, I know.
...to my detriment, cos it often leaks out a little bit later doesn't it.
Ever been out on a date with a girl, where it's just trickled down your leg, and you wish it hadn't and you're thinking, 'what if she gets my trousers off later – she might smell or see it'.
(Squeaking) What? She might what?
I don't know.
Ricky laughs.
I don't know what I said there.
Right.
Rick, I had for Christmas something which i think might excite you, and interest you, cos I know you're obsessed and interested by facts.
Yeah.
Strange noises.
Don't fiddle with the microphone, everyone can hear that.
Well, I was just looking what it was underneath it.
Stop! Listen to what I'm saying.
I – no, no, listen, let me explain.
People could hear you moving the microphone.
Could they?
Yeah, I could hear it in my headphones.
You know it's the little pop-shield that goes over the mic, I was gonna see, where the, what the, what way the mic was facing, so I just had a little look.
Who cares, no-one's interested, leave it, Karl will tell you if there's a problem.
Alright.
(In a high voice) Why am I talking like that?
Ricky laughs.
So this is a book, it's just facts and trivia, it's edited by Sir Isaac Asimov.
Oh yeah.
Who i think's dead, so I don't know when my parents bought this book, I assume it's sort of from a second hand shop or something.
Right.

It's quite old, but I got it for Christmas, I keep meaning to bring it in, cos there are, generally the facts are quite sensible in here, and I like to think if Isaac's been involved, there probably substantiated, it's not like, just this nonsense on the web...
Or, or...
I think this is probably true stuff...
Or up in Greggs the Bakers, that Karl gets most of his facts from.
The ancient Egyptians trained baboons to wait on tables.
Ricky chuckles.
Karl – fascinated.
Brilliant.
That's fantastic.
But, what, what, my point about that is why did they stop?
Yeah.
It's genius, that's a genius idea. Would you not want to go to a restaurant where they had baboons serving?
No, I tell you what happened...
I've been to a few...

It might have been like the Planet of The Apes and they sort of rebelled, one of 'em could talk, one of 'em take his order, and one day went, “do you want fries with that” and the bloke got really annoyed and started answering him back and there was some sort of rebellion.
Right, right, right, right.
Plant of The Apes isn't true is it?
It's not...
It's a film.
It's not a documentary.
Right, okay.

I wonder, cos what I like the idea of having baboons is the fact that I reckon they're, like I have trouble, difficult, and I'm sure you do Karl, like working out that ten percent, you know, on a bill. I reckon baboons would find that particularly hard, I reckon you could get away with under-tipping them all the time
Yeah, yeah, exactly!
Just not leaving enough and then legging it.
Ricky makes ape noises.
They go away and you go “sucker.”
Yeah, exactly, so I'd love to see some baboon restaurants, if there's any restaurateurs out there, Sir Terence Conran or someone...

Could I, could I sugg... if you do go to a restaurant and are waited on by... please don't order the banana daiquiri, cos it comes half-eaten, they can't help their little selves, they really can't, they're okay with like, you know beef and steak and chips and all that, but er, but you know there's a little monkey and I go, did you bite...
Ricky does unintelligible monkey speech (not an impression, he just garbles every syllable.)
Can you imagine that though, baboons serving, waiting tables, it's genius, just stop to think about that, it's absolutely incredible.
Yeah.
It's absolute dynamite.
Yeah, that's a good fact.
See, zoos would be a lot more popular, it that was like the canteen, you could go in and just...
If they were serving tickets two, yeah, one child, one adult, okay go through there.
But I think they should do other things, you know in The Flintstones they used to mix cement, in that bird's kind of beak.
Pelican, yeah. Yeah.
We should just start doing that again.
Ricky laughs.
Cos that also happened in ancient times.
Yeah exactly!
According to The Flintstones.
Yeah, before they had proper cement mixers, that's what they did.
That's how they did it.
Definitely.
Just, just er, animal facts. I remembered one in the week.
Go on.
There was, you know them two gay American men who have, have tigers?
Well, they're not necessarily gay.
There not necessarily - no-one actually knows if they are gay...
(Whispering) They are.
Alright.
Okay they are.
Gilbert and George is it? No that's those artists.
Yeah.
What are they called – Siegfried and Roy.
Yeah...
But anyway...
Who may or may not be gay.
Yeah, and if they are... so what?
And if they are... so what, but if they're not and they...
I just said that so you knew, knew who I was talking about...
Okay, the two gay ones, go on.
The two possibly gay guys.
Loads of people have tigers.
Let's not worry about libel law, anymore then or...
If you shave a tiger's head...
Ricky and Steve giggle.
Whoa, whoa, whoa... whoa, okay, you've gotta treat that sentence with a lot more reverence than you did, think what you're saying, if you shave a tiger's head.
Not just it's head, it's whole body.
Oh, sorry, sorry...
Oh sorry...
Sorry I thought you were, I thought you were getting weird, go on, if you shave a tiger, yeah go on.
It's still stripy underneath.
Yeah.
The skin, the skin's stripy...
Is it like rock?
Goes all the way through?
All the way through.
Yeah.
That's amazing.
Where did you hear that one?
That's, I remembered that like I was watching...
Was that a drunk just shouting it in the street?
Ricky cackles.
(As a drunk) “I shaved a tiger and it's still stripy, get out of it.” Yeah.
'I must make a note of that', says Karl.

(Laughing) Yeah, that's an interesting fact. Well you know a polar bear? Polar bears' skin is actually black and it's fur is transparent, not white and it gives the illusion; so it gets all the radiation possible from the sun, but is still camouflaged.
I don't understand that Rick, sorry, you lost me, if its skin's black...
A Polar bear's skin's black.
... and it's fur's translucent.
And its fur's translucent.
So why is it white when we see it?
Well, just cos the light hits it...
The sun reflects...
...and it makes it look white. Yeah, if you look at each individual hair, it's actually translucent.
So at night it would be black?
Well... everything is.
Is it?
Ooo... not bright stuff, Rick.
Ricky wheezes with laughter.
You've embarrassed yourself! Play a record! “I know all about animals and stuff!” Do you Rick?
Good Souls - Starsailor.
Alive - P.O.D.
P.O.D – bit of pod there, Alive, that's growing on me.
Yeah, it's not bad.
You know, it rocks, we've gotta give it that.
I will certainly give it that Rick.
Yeah, XFM 104.9, Ricky Gervais.
With me, Steve Merchant.
Ricky and Steve Giggle
So more from the facts and trivia book, edited, as I say by Sir Isaac Asimov, so not just overheard on the tube, or by a drunk.
Steve clears his throat.
Well he might have overheard them on a tube by a drunk and just put 'em in the book.
Yes. Listen to the whole fact here, before you make any judgements.
Okay.
Sauerkraut was renamed 'Liberty Cabbage' by Americans during World War I.
Sure.
In their denunciation of all things German, some Americans actually kicked Dachshunds.
Silence.
The little dogs?
Yeah.
Stunned silence.

Little German dogs, just gave 'em a kicking, cos they were German, well they derived from Germany. I don't know if they got to like a small French village and just said “Bring out your Dachshunds” “Why, what are you going to do to them?” “Nothing, give 'em a little bit of food or something.
Ricky laughs
“You're not gonna kick 'em are you...”
“Got some milk for 'em!”
“...cos I've heard about you Americans.”
“No, no, just bring out the little (antagonised) sausage dog”, “Well you say that aggressively.”
“You said that aggressively, like you...”
“No, bring out the little (nicely) sausage dog, okay.”
“Well, you're not gonna hurt him then?”
“Of course I'm not.”
“If you hurt it now, it's like against the Geneva convention and everything.”
“I'm not gonna kick it.”
“Well, I didn't even bring up kicking.”
“I didn't even mention kicking, so why have you, why have you done that?”
“I don't know.”
“Well, I – I – I haven't got a Dachshund.”
“Have – oh.”
“Sacre bleu.”
“Yeah, sorry.”
“That thing down my trousers is just a baguette.”
Ricky chuckles.
Oh yeah, d'ya remember that Karl? D'ya Remember that?
A dynamite fact, a dynamite fact.
Baguettes were invented by Napoleon, so he could carry 'em down his leg.

Let me just find... there's one more here, that I thought might, I know that there's a lot of those kind of amusing laws and stuff, antiquated laws and that on the web and things, but again it's Asimov, I'm thinking it's true. City Ordinance Number 352 in Pacific Grove California makes it a misdemeanour to kill or threaten a butterfly.
Threaten?!
Yeah, you can't even threaten a butterfly.
So it goes...
Don't even look at it aggressively.
Yeah, butterfly comes down says “What you looking at?” I go “Nothing.” He goes “Judge!” “What?” “Bloke looking at me with a net.”
“I wasn't doing anything, I wasn't doing any-”
“I'm fishing.”

At the Pan-American exposition in Buffalo in 1901, President William McKinley received a line of citizens, shaking hands with each, in the line was a man with a handkerchief covering one hand. Neither of the two secret service men guarding the President was curious enough to take a look at what might be under the handkerchief in the hand of the man, Leon Czolgosz, an anarchist. What he had was a loaded revolver and when the President thrust his right hand out for the shake, Czolgosz fired twice; McKinley died a week later.
A moment of silence in memory of the fallen leader
So, what he did there, it was outwit the might of presumably the FBI, or the Secret Service, by covering the gun with a handkerchief.
Clever.
That's brilliant.
It's absolute genius.

Just think how they had to explain that, and they go “What, how did they, how did he get close enough and shoot the President?” and they go, “Uh, we didn't see the gun”, “Why?”, “He covered it with a hankie.” “Did he? Oh, well you're not to blame then.” “Exactly! We couldn't, we can't compete with that sort of... you know.” “Didn't you think to look under the hankie?”
“No.”

“No I was just, probably just thought it was a hand.” “Of course, cos that's where the hand would be. Did you not think he was probably holding a gun or something?” “Didn't do that, we didn't train, we didn't do 'hiding it with a hankie', did we?” “Alright, well if you didn't do it, then it's not your fault. Don't worry about it.” But he lived did he, for a week?
